This board is for the discussion of news, world events, political issues, and other related topics.

Off-topic and /b/-tier threads will be deleted (and possibly earn you a ban, if you persist). Unless they are quality, well thought out, well written posts, the following are some examples of off-topic and/or /b/-tier threads:

>Red pill me on X. (with no extra content or input of your own)
>Are X white?
>Is X degeneracy?
>How come X girls love Y guys so much?
>If X is true, then how come Y? Checkmate Z.

The variety of threads allowed here are very flexible and we believe in freedom of speech, but we expect a high level of discourse befitting of the board. Attempts to disrupt the board will not be tolerated, nor will calls to disrupt other boards and sites.

If you want a place to discuss topics not related to news, world events, or politics, please try /bant/ - International/Random,
Check the catalog before posting a new thread!Reply to existing threads about a topic instead of starting a new one. New users who do not abide by this principle will be temporarily blocked from creating threads. Mods will delete obvious duplicate threads and spam without notice. Don't bitch because your twitter screencap thread got deleted; there are probably other threads about it. Go look!

Race is mostly cosmetic like a skin in a video game but your race does determine some biases and some features.

Pic related shows the differemce between the negroid and the europoid. The negroid will have big fat lips and a big fat nose and prognathism. The europoid will have a needle lips, needle nose nose, and other crocodilian features. Again these are race families and they have racial variations (Slav vs German, Bantu vs Ethiopid) within them.

But the point is they exist, and this affects politics

>>468763218
> Possible side effects include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, headache, fatigue, indigestion/heartburn, dizziness, abdominal distension, belching, hypoglycemia (low blood glucose) in people with type 2 diabetes, flatulence, gastroenteritis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).[15] It can also cause pancreatitis, gastroparesis, and bowel obstruction.[35]

> The US FDA label for semaglutide contains a boxed warning for thyroid C-cell tumors in rodents.[13][14][15][25] It is unknown whether semaglutide causes thyroid C-cell tumors, including medullary thyroid carcinoma, in humans.[13][14][15][25][36]

> Contraindications
> Data from rodent studies of GLP-1-mediated thyroid C-cell hyperplasia[37] indicates that use is contraindicated in people with a personal or family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma or with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2.[14][13]

Akkkshuallllyyy, the shitting-yourself is "shitting out of your mouth."
The drug reduces "gastric emptying," which is to say, it slows down the progress of food through your gastrointestinal tract. This helps you not feel as hungry, and ultimately eat less, which is all weight loss amounts to, ever.
If your guts completely freeze up, the bacteria working on poop in your colon migrate up into your small intestine, and turn that food also into poop. When it gets to the stalled food in your stomach, you vomit shit out of your mouth like a South Park episode.

>>468763825
Alpert Medical student here,
Good fats are essential for your health. Animal fat can be considered “regular fat”. 
I’d avoid vegetable fat or nut fat like the plague.
The biggest problem in the U.S. is carb, not fat. Carb in the form of sugar, particularly.
We did an experiment involving animals where we fed a high sugar diet to one, a balanced diet to another, and a high fat/high protein diet to another.
High sugar became obese and retarded.
Balanced diet remained at original weight.
High fat/protein diet gained muscle mass and slept less than the other two, ate less, and seemed to have more energy.

In the second phase of the program, candidate one had sugar removed altogether from its diet. It experienced severe withdrawals comparable to heroine.

Sugar is as easy to kick as heroine. You think about that.

>>468768584
>Pot calls kettle 
The Jewish communities of the Balkans were boosted in the 15th and 16th centuries by the arrival of Jewish refugees fleeing the Spanish and Portuguese Inquisitions. Sultan Bayezid II of the Ottoman Empire welcomed the Jewish refugees into his Empire. Jews became involved in trade between the various provinces in the Ottoman Empire, becoming especially important in the salt trade.[3] In 1663, the Jewish population of Belgrade was 800.[4]
While the rest of modern-day Serbia was still ruled by the Ottoman Empire, territory of present-day Vojvodina was part of the Habsburg monarchy. In 1782, Emperor Joseph II issued the Edict of Tolerance, giving Jews some measure of religious freedom. The Edict attracted Jews to many parts of the Monarchy. The Jewish communities of Vojvodina flourished, and by the end of the 19th century the region had nearly 40 Jewish communities.[5]

Based on the synagogue system.
> The earliest organization of the Christian churches in Judea was similar to that of Jewish synagogues, who were governed by a council of elders (presbyteroi). In Acts 11:30 and 15:22, we see this collegiate system of government in Jerusalem, and in Acts 14:23, the Apostle Paul ordains elders in the churches he founded. Initially, these presbyters were apparently identical with the overseers (episcopate, i.e., bishops), as such passages as Acts 20:17 and Titus 1:5,7 indicate, and the terms were interchangeable.

>muh 680

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_England

> Jews in England were completely dependent on the will of the Crown. English Jews were legally under the jurisdiction of the king, who offered them protection in return for their economic function.[20] As "royal serfs", they were allowed freedom of the king's highways, exemption from tolls, the ability to hold land directly from the king, and physical protection in the vast network of royal castles built to assert Norman authority.[21]
>The Jews of London were the responsibility of the Constable of the Tower and for this reason they were able to seek refuge in the Tower of London when at risk of mob violence. This was resorted to on a number of occasions, with large numbers staying there, sometimes for months at a time. There are records of a body of Jewish men-at-arms forming part of the garrison of the Tower in 1267, during a civil war.[22]

>In June, PiS president Jarosław Kaczyński stated that the issue of relocation of migrants in the European Union must be submitted to a referendum.
>The subject of the referendum will be whether we agree to a forced relocation mechanism, not whether we help someone in a difficult situation or not, said government spokesman Piotr Müller on Thursday, commenting on the position of the Polish Catholic Church, which opposed the instrumental use of refugees "for political games" and assessed that a referendum was not needed to work out solutions to migration challenges.
>In the statement, members of the Council of the Polish Episcopate pointed out that for a long time, the increased presence of migration issues in the public debate has been noticeable. "We appeal to all its participants, politicians, publicists and the media to present the situation of refugees and migrants in Poland and the European Union in a reliable and responsible, factually correct and free from ideology. We strongly warn against their instrumental use in political games and the development of xenophobic attitudes. Such actions are incompatible with Christian teaching."
>In their opinion, "anti-refugee or anti-immigration narratives not only shape social attitudes, but also have an impact on the lives of specific people." "They are also destructive to attempts at a responsible, joint search for adequate responses, and they deprive the refugee and the migrant of human dignity" - they assessed.
>"We ask that in the search for solutions to complicated migration problems, we ask that you be guided above all by the attitudes of openness, respect towards migrants and refugees and the broadly understood common good" - they appealed.

>>468777331
It’s always been in the deal between church and crown. Constantine himself invented serfdom at the exact same time he institutionalized Christianity.
> A clause to that effect was inserted under Henry I in some manuscripts of the so-called Leges Edwardi Confessoris ("Laws of Edward the Confessor"). Henry granted a charter to Rabbi Joseph, the chief Rabbi of London, and his followers. Under this charter, Jews were permitted to move about the country without paying tolls, to buy and sell, to sell their pledges after holding them a year and a day, to be tried by their peers, and to be sworn on the Torah rather than on a Christian Bible. Special weight was attributed to a Jew's oath, which was valid against that of twelve Christians. The sixth clause of the charter was especially important: it granted to Jews the right to move wherever they wanted, as if they were the king's own property ("sicut res propriæ nostræ").[19] As the king's property, English Jews could be mortgaged whenever the monarch needed to raise revenue and could be taxed without the permission of Parliament, eventually becoming the main taxpaying population.[23]
>English Jews experienced a "golden age" of sorts under Henry II in the late 12th century due to huge economic expansion and increased demand for credit. Major Jewish fortunes were made in London, Oxford, Lincoln, Bristol, and Norwich.[24] The Crown, in turn, capitalized on the prosperity of its Jews.

>>468777740
https://www.britannica.com/summary/serfdom
> From about the 2nd century AD, large privately owned estates in the Roman Empire that had been worked by slaves were broken up and given to peasant farmers. These farmers came to depend on larger landowners for protection in turbulent times, and swearing fealty to a proprietor became common practice. In 332 Constantine I established serfdom legally by requiring tenant farmers to pay labour services to their lords. As serfs, they could not marry, change occupations, or move without the permission of their lords, to whom they were required to give a major portion of their harvest. The development of centralized political power, the labour shortage caused by the Black Death, and endemic peasant uprisings in the 14th and 15th centuries led to the gradual emancipation of serfs in western Europe.

>>468770620
I assume those variations are already accounted for in the 5 year figure, it affects things equally either way. Objects with higher mass:area will lose speed slower. If it takes a satellite with sail like solar panels 5 years to decay, nuts and bolts will take significantly longer.

I'm not saying Kessler syndrome isn't over hyped, I agree with you on that. Even if a lot of LEO satellites were blown up, I'm sure there would plenty of launch windows to access space. Some useful orbits might be excessively polluted, but less efficient alternatives could be used to get the required coverage.

>>468768925
mcdonald is a license the shops aren't owned by the actual corporation
the manager paid for the license to use mcdonald's themes, items and intellectual property. Everything is paid by the manager, the shop the worker's wages and the manager has to pay the actual corporation a certain tax to maintain the license
this is why sometimes you can find amazing high quality mcdonalds while other mcdonalds are staffed with niggers and the floor smells like shit
most fast food corporations use Franchising because it's cheaper and it allows for better growth since anyone with money can open a shop if they want
very few shops if any are actually run by mcdonalds themselves and if they are, they're probably in some very big urban centers

The thinly-protected, 1950s-vintage BTR-50 might not be the worst vehicle the Russian army has sent in a direct assault on Ukrainian positions, but it’s probably the oldest.

And while it’s safer for Russian troops to ride in a 70-year-old BTR-50 with its 10-millimeter-thick armor than to ride in, say, a brand-new Chinese golf cart, it’s still an ominous sign for Russia that more BTR-50s are appearing on the battlefields of eastern Ukraine as Russia’s wider war on Ukraine grinds toward its 28th month.

“Without mechanized units fully equipped with proper combat vehicles like tanks, achieving swift and decisive penetration of defenses will be very challenging,” Ukrainian analysis group Frontelligence Insight explained. “This limitation is likely to result in slower and more limited advances, hampering the overall progress of Russian forces.”

>>468773842
The BTR-50 is a 15-ton, diesel-fueled armored tractor with two crew and space for up to 20 passengers. It usually packs a heavy machine gun.

The Soviet Union developed the BTR-50 in the early 1950s. It entered service in 1954 and, for the next 12 years, was the Soviet army’s main fighting vehicle. BTR-50 crews would haul soldiers into battle, protect them as they dismounted and then support them with its machine gun.

The BTR-50 is lightly-armed and thinly-armored by even 1960s standards, however. When the heavier, and more heavily-armed, BMP-1 debuted in 1966, thousands of BTR-50s cascaded to second-line units. The BTRs hauled artillery, engineers and anti-aircraft guns until MT-LB tractors began displacing the older vehicles from those roles, too.

The present-day Russian military had few uses for a BTR-50 until, around 15 months into the wider war in Ukraine, Russia’s monthly losses of modern armored vehicles exceeded Russia’s monthly generation of reasonably modern replacement vehicles—either through production of brand-new vehicles or the recovery, from long-term storage, of vehicles from the 1980s or later.
(2/3)

>>468774026
The Kremlin began pulling BTR-50s out of open storage in early 2023. It seems Russian commanders initially assigned the vehicles to rear-area support roles and kept them away from the front line. But then, in late 2023, BTR-50s began showing up in Russian assault groups in the east.

Six months later, the Russians have lost in battle at least four BTR-50s that the analysts at Oryx can confirm. One got hit by a Javelin anti-tank missile while attacking Ukrainian lines west of Novomykhailivka on or right before Sunday.

The Ukrainian army’s 79th Air Assault Brigade holds the line in that area—and that brigade’s anti-tank missileers are notoriously bloodthirsty. It’s unsafe to send a modern T-72 tank with hundreds of millimeters of armor against the 79th Air Assault Brigade; it’s suicide to send a BTR-50 with just 10 millimeters of armor.

That BTR-50’s doomed assault is indicative of a wider problem. Tens of billions of dollars worth of fresh military aid the United States and the European Union are on the way to Ukraine. Perhaps hoping to capture additional territory ahead of that aid arriving, the Russians launched a new offensive two weeks ago—rolling south across Ukraine’s northern border with Russia.
(3/3)

>2018 Farm Bill legalized all "hemp" provided it did not contain 0.3% or more THC - the chemical that produces marijuana intoxication. 

... the problem?

>the natural state of THC exists in the plant as a different chemical: THCa

>this chemical acid is broken down by heat "decarboxylation" (e.g., by smoking or baking) in order to form intoxicating THC

Therefore, all cannabis plants are considered "hemp" under Federal law - even those containing high amounts of THCa since they don't contain any THC. 

https://thehill.com/homenews/4564181-2018-farm-bill-hemp-cannabis-attorneys-general/

>The Federal Analogue Act, 21 U.S.C. § 813, is a section of the United States Controlled Substances Act passed in 1986 which allows any chemical "substantially similar" to a controlled substance listed in Schedule I or II to be treated as if it were listed in Schedule I, but only if intended for human consumption.

I think even the DEA has realized it's a losing battle with how fast new isomers are brought to market and how many states have tried banning analogues but end up getting overturned by state courts or tied up in lawsuits

It was either illegal weed that they were hoping to slip under the radar with all of the other legal shit being sold out there, or it was legally grown hemp flowers that had been sprayed with THCa (or who knows what else) that had been legally extracted from legal hemp.

If you want legit weed in a state where it isn't legalized, buy it from your neighborhood drug dealer.

mulch pyramids around trees only benefit the mulch merchant.

fish and seaweed emulsion

>>468764194
Any day now
He gobbles Provigil (generic name modafinil) while guzzling alcohol. Surprised he doesn't look even more rough honestly. For those who don't know modafinil is a stimulant that is used by people with narcolepsy, chronic fatigue, or for people in certain jobs that require extreme hours such as in the military (special forces soldiers on long missions, pilots, etc.) It's similar to Adderall but supposedly less addictive. 
>Mixing alcohol and Modafinil can lead a variety of reactions ranging from blackouts to significantly increased alcohol tolerance.
>Modafinil inhibits the reuptake of dopamine (increases the effects of dopamine)
>Alcohol increases production of dopamine
So with the increased alcohol tolerance, along with the increased dopaminergic response to the alcohol, then you get this zombified creature.

>>468767508
The analogy is the difference between Newtonian and Relativistic mechanics

At slow speeds, p = mv (momentum = mass times velocity)
But actually there is another term there, Gamma, 1/Sqrt(1-(v^2/c^2))
At low speeds that is practically 1, but once you get into percentages of the speed of light, then it becomes significant

That analogy may hold for gravity, where on the scale of our Sun and Earth it's F = Gmm/r^2
But maybe that G has some scaling, or the r^2 term actually has some other parameter that is negligible at low mass.

>>468771478
CERN. Remote viewing. Quantum physics. Here you go. Here we describe a new concept for a dark matter experiment, employing superfluid He as a detector for dark matter that is close to the mass of the proton, of order 1 GeV/. The QUEST-DMC detector concept is based on quasiparticle detection in a bolometer cell by a nanomechanical resonator. In this paper we develop the energy measurement methodology and detector response model, simulate candidate dark matter signals and expected background interactions, and calculate the sensitivity of such a detector. We project that such a detector can reach sub-eV nuclear recoil energy threshold, opening up new windows on the parameter space of both spin-dependent and spin-independent interactions of light dark matter candidates.
You use recreated dark matter to find Dark matter with a mass of order or below the mass of the proton, commonly referred to as the “sub-GeV/” mass region

>>468773044
One interesting observation in helium superfluids is that helium can creep over the rim of its container against gravity, as illustrated in Figure 4. To understand the physics behind this phenomenon, let us analyze the forces exerted on an individual molecule. Let us assume a helium molecule near the wall inside the container at location A. It is pulled by three forces: W, the upward adhesion to nearby molecules of the container; G, the downward force of the molecule's weight, minus the buoyancy if it is in the fluid; and M, the cohesion with the surrounding helium molecules inside the container.
the helium liquid, cohesion M is a result of London dispersion forces. In superfluids, the London dispersion forces are
negligible, and the cohesion will reduce to zero, i.e., M = 0.
Even though there is no cohesion between superfluid molecules, adhesion may still exist between the superfluid and its container. In the case of a container made of glass, i.e., SiO2, the oxygen and silicon atoms are held together by covalent bonds, which results in an uneven distribution of electrons in silicon dioxide and introduces local fields. The positive regions of these fields create adhesion to the superfluid molecules. Therefore, W is the adhesion due to this type of interaction. W Capillary Force Analysis. The creeping phenomenon of superfluids. This is an effect in which superfluids defy gravity by creeping over the walls of their container.
>>468772814
A helium molecule located at point A inside the container is pulled upward by the adhesion force to the container, W. It is also affected by the downward force of gravity, G. In superfluids, the cohesion force M becomes negligible due to the disappearance of London dispersions. Without cohesion, the superfluid molecules are pulled up by the molecules on the container wall because Coulomb's force W is much stronger than gravity G.
Coulomb's force is significantly stronger than gravity, making G negligible when compared to W. So, in the absence of cohesion in the superfluid, the net force pulls the molecule up along the container wall. As a result, a thin film of superfluid molecules covers the entire surface of the container. However, the intermolecular force is only effective at short distances.
When the helium film becomes too thick, gravity pulls the excess superfluid down along the container wall, as shown in Figure 4, causing it to drip off the bottom of the container.
Indeed, the creeping effect is not unique to superfluids,

Are seed oils really as bad as people say they are?
>>468776589
yes, shit literally kills you and gives you cancer and all kinds of other diseases

I really doubt that seed oils themselves are as bad as people make them out to be
• Unsaturated Vegetable Oils: Toxic
https://raypeat.com/articles/articles/unsaturated-oils.shtml
• Unsaturated fatty acids: Nutritionally essential, or toxic?
https://raypeat.com/articles/articles/unsaturatedfats.shtml

https://raypeat.com/articles/articles/diabetes.shtml

https://raypeat.com/articles/nutrition/oils-in-context.shtml

https://raypeat.com/articles/articles/fishoil.shtml

• About Ray Peat
https://raypeat.com/about.shtml
>I have a Ph.D. in Biology from the University of Oregon, with specialization in physiology.

• Unsaturated Vegetable Oils: Toxic
https://raypeat.com/articles/articles/unsaturated-oils.shtml
>Q: You say vegetable oils are hazardous to your health. What vegetable oils are you talking about?

>Mainly, I'm referring to sⲟybean oil, corn oil, safflower oil, canola, sesame oil, sunflower seed oil, palm oil, and any others that are labeled as "unsaturated" or "polyunsaturated." Almond oil, which is used in many cosmetics, is very unsaturated.

>Chemically, the material that makes these oils very toxic is the polyunsaturated fat itself. These unsaturated oils are found in very high concentrations in many seeds, and in the fats of animals that have eaten a diet containing them. The fresh oils, whether cold pressed or consumed as part of the living plant material, are intrinsically toxic, and it is not any special industrial treatment that makes them toxic. Since these oils occur in other parts of plants at lower concentration, and in the animals which eat the plants, it is impossible to eat a diet which lacks them, unless special foods are prepared in the laboratory.
no, they're worse

>>468769591
>The problem is using recordings of other people's voices to train bots. Impressionists aren't bots.
You really don't get the point.
If it's not illegal for an impressionist to listen to a voice recording and duplicate the enunciation, then you cannot make it illegal for a bot to do it either. 
It's called "precedent". It's a thing in law. 
The thing in question, as Scarlett is doing, is trying to argue that you cannot make money off of it, NOT that you can't do it in the first place.
Similarly, I am perfectly free to make AI pics of Scarlett if I want to, what is called into question is if I intend to make money off of them. And even then that's a grey area in law. An artist can paint a portrait of somebody AND sell it, and there is nothing the person depicted can do.

>t. simpleton who cant differentiate between basic biochemical processes. 

>Anaerobic exercise is a type of exercise that breaks down glucose in the body without using oxygen; anaerobic means "without oxygen".[1] In practical terms, this means that anaerobic exercise is more intense, but shorter in duration than aerobic exercise.[2]
> The biochemistry of anaerobic exercise involves a process called glycolysis, in which glucose is converted to adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary source of energy for cellular reactions

>>468775862
Vit A will increase lung cancer if you smoke? Hm, let me look it up
RESULTS
Four studies contributing 109,394 subjects were available for analysis. The average daily beta-carotene dosage in these trials ranged from 20 to 30 mg daily. Among current smokers, beta-carotene supplementation was found to be significantly associated with an increased risk of lung cancer (odds ratio [OR], 1.24; 95% confidence interval [95% CI], 1.10–1.39). Among former smokers, there was no significant increase noted (OR, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.84–1.45). In a sample of 47 common multivitamins, beta-carotene was present in 70% of the identified formulas. The median dosage of beta-carotene was 0.3 mg (range, 0–17.2 mg) daily. The beta-carotene content was found to be significantly higher among multivitamins sold to improve visual health than among other multivitamins, with a median daily dosage of 3 mg (range, 0–24 mg).

CONCLUSIONS
High-dose beta-carotene supplementation appears to increase the risk of lung cancer among current smokers. Although beta-carotene was prevalent in multivitamins, high-dose beta-carotene was observed among multivitamin formulas sold to promote visual health. Cancer 2008. © 2008 American Cancer Society.

>>468775817
protips for escaping this trap in the interim. Almost every "remote" job will want you to still be working in whicever Province and they will want you to prove it by showing your internet connection yada yada.. The only way to get around this is by using a dVPN like Mysterium that makes it appear that you're at a residential address in whatever city it is you say you're in.. 
But, you cant just install a dVPN on a work laptop or whatever and they would be able to see it with their monitoring software if regardless of if you're using your own computer.. So, what you need to do is, or what i do is, I have an Intel NUC, you can use whatever, another laptop idc, and you connect it to your WiFi wherever you are living, you run the dVPN on that laptop and then you set the laptop to act as a router, you wire that laptop into an actual router(becaus you will usually need to use more than just a work laptop, will need to use a VoIP phone, etc..) ... So that way there is no way for them to tell that you're using a dVPN and are out of the country.
If you're just getting a job and you're already outside of the country it is a huge pain in the ass because they will send the equipment last minute and you will need to have your friend or family rush it to you form their address and it will cost like 800 dollars and probably wont get there in time.. so you would have to fake being sick and try to start at the next months training session or what have you. The best bet, if you're a leaf or a westerner that is still in country is to get remote work and thenjust take the equipment with you and do what I just said with the dVPN and routing...

Hope this helps you guys. Like I said in my OG post, if you're not doing some form of this you are getting assfucked, and even with a basic bitch call center remote job from the West you can live like a King elsewhere

If you haven't seen it yet, check out "The Big Heist" with Donald Sutherland and John Heard. It's based on a book about the Lufthansa heist. Sutherland plays Jimmy Burke (and somehow makes it work in its own interpretive way) and Heard plays a local cop investigating the heist and does a great job in the role. It's a little known made for TV movie that aired on USA around 2000, 2001. They take a lot of license in telling the story relative to what people generally know about it. The casting is very interesting and for the most part quite good.

I ran to the gate and boarded, then took a five hour flight aboard a DC10 that had maybe five passengers on it. I got a ton of attention from the stewardesses because i was still a cute kid flying cross country alone.

Yeah, those days are long gone. But at least we got to live through them.

>>468766343
Don't care. He's the ONLY ONE who voted no against Israels right to defend themselves.
Capitalism is a jewish pyramid scheme which runs on perpetual geometric expansion of the fiat money supply and inevitably periodically fails through either hyperinflation or massive depression and cancellation of large swaths of the fiat money supply, where the working class (plebs) have their savings cancelled in "bank-failures" or "bank bail-ins", like what happened during the Cyprus banking crisis.
Capitalism cannot afford to purchase its own aggregate internal production at a price which it is profitable to produce that output at, unless the money needed to make up the difference is constantly being introduced into the system, such as by creating fiat money (or more fiat money than is already in existence) or allowing counterfeiting or debasing of sound money such as silver coins, such as by reducing the purity or the weight of the coins.
However, the money creation needs to be continuous to enable continued capitalist production.
And because of the law of diminishing returns, the rate at which new money is created needs to accelerate over time (the money supply growth needs to be geometric). Otherwise, the rate of expansion of the money supply gradually approaches 0% of the already existing money supply over time, as the money supply grows.
For example expanding the money supply from $10 trillion to $11 trillion within a year is a yearly growth of 10%. But expanding it further, from $11 trillion to $12 trillion in the subsequent year is only a growth of 9.(09)%. For the money supply to grow another 10% in the second year, it needs to grow from $11 trillion to $12.1 trillion rather than just $12 trillion.
GDP is not economic activity but the estimated and imputed rate of exchange of money per year.
Inflation, including due to scarcity, inflates the GDP, deflation, including due to abundance, deflates the GDP.
Fiat money is not wealth but merely claims on wealth.
Wealth is what you spend fiat money on, not fiat money itself.
Capitalism is not a closed loop system
The Federal Reserve and its franchises were created in 1913 to stabilize the US currency by issuing Federal Reserve Notes and they are denominated in units of a dollar (US$), like many other issued notes denominated in dollars such as fiat US Notes, non-fiat US Gold Notes and non-fiat US Silver Notes. Specifically, FIAT Federal Reserve Notes were intended to be a NON-INTEREST BEARING TOOL FOR THE CITIZENS to facilitate commerce, that is all. The Federal Reserve franchises were created to stabilize DEPOSITORY institutions, NOT to prop up insolvent securities firms (ALL of the NYFed’s largest owners are securities firms, aka the NYFed’s 24 primary dealers). 

We entrusted the Federal Reserve with the issuance of our currency so they may stabilize US commerce and to back our currency with gold. Instead, the Federal Reserve’s privately-incorporated franchises have transformed to vassal corporations that PRIMARILY ENRICH THE NYFed’s PRIMARY DEALERS and debauch the value of our currency with ever-increasing national debt (including both marketable debt (now ~$34T) and intragovernmental debt (now well over a $100T annually)). 

The 2008 failures are repeatedly rewarded/bailed out for their insolvencies and failures with the creation of even more borrowed private Federal Reserve Notes, the creation of new LLCs and four rounds of QE counterfeiting (so far). Endless debt-issuance and the necessary and constant creation of new financial laws and ‘rules’ abet the NYFed in this self-enrichment scheme. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve Note is now being rejected on the world stage due to the blatant abuse of this power, which also further debauches the US$ globally.

The NYFed’s primary dealers benefit from BOTH the liabilities and assets of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet, the SOMA (System Open Market Account).
During QE, the NYFed creates reserves out of thin air and uses these reserves to purchase treasuries from its primary dealers (this is the asset side of the Fed’s balance sheet). 
The primary dealers then earn interest on these reserves (called Interest on Reserve Balances, aka IORB) at the NYFed (this is the liabilities side of the Fed’s balance sheet). Pic related

We have devolved into a never-ending loop of newly-issued public debt and more taxes to pay its interest. This constant skimming is enabled and perpetuated by the NYFed b/c they create reserves OUT OF THIN AIR to purchase treasuries from a few select banks and then pay interest to the same few select banks on those very reserves. This is Quantitative Easing (aka QE).

The US is now issuing treasuries to pay interest on treasuries.
The Federal Reserve is now operating like a hedge fund, financing long term assets with short term liabilities.

http://www.nber.org/papers/w30749

the Fed went from holding mostly non interest-bearing liabilities—cash in circulation—aka Federal Reserve Notes in circulation in 2007 to holding mostly interest-bearing liabilities today (liabilities of interest paid out to primary dealers (for IORB) and MMFs (for reverse repos))

this is because FIAT NOTES are supposed to JUST BE A TOOL to facilitate commerce/trade, this is the fucking whole reason we hired the fucking Fed-- to provide a stable currency, lolololol, NOT to prop up the NYFed's primary dealers and their private securities LLC firms, but to stabilize DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS.

1 fiat should never earn interest, it is a tool for commerce between citizens, as originally intended
2 the currency itself should never be used as an investment (no bond debt for currency issuance, as is failing right now before our very eyes)
3 metals should never have paper contracts

I think the Terminator part is a small but distinct sect. Harley riders are usually old ass boomers that still believe in anything American being good. Harleys are realistically dog shit. The traditional single crank pin v-twin is unbalanced, literally shakes itself apart and is slow torquey but you can get the same amount of torque from a modern inline twin with the 270 degree crank. Or even just throw on another fuckin crank pin but it's what has been tradition and it's admirable in a way.

I rode a friend's Buel, which was just a Sportster motor bored out and tuned to rip, but that thing vibrated so much, it felt like something was wrong.

It's a raw feeling though, and I think that's what really resonates with those men, that feeling of fighting against a powerful machine between you legs and taming it.

I've not seen a decent thread on here in a while about anything historic and important to understanding ruling classes and such, which remains relevant politically today.

Pic related is a book I just picked up and will be reading from during this thread. 

Drop in and share your thoughts about anything relevant to the broader topic. Let's talk about something other than dead women, gay paintings, and psyop versions of the truth.
>In an extraordinary exposition, Lorenzen – an expert beekeeper and student of contemporary spiritual science – describes the 'Logos mysteries', based at the ancient temple of Artemis in Ephesus, where priestesses were known as 'Melissas' ('honeybees') and the sacrificial priests were called 'Essenes' (or 'bee-kings'). These cultic mysteries, he says, bore remarkable parallels to the workings of a bee colony – specifically in the relationship between the queen and worker bees to the spiritual 'group-soul' of the bees.
Lorenzen commences his unique study with a discussion of flowers and insects, exploring their common origins. He then describes the beginnings of the honeybee, its connection with the fig wasp, and the subsequent controlled transformation of the latter that took place in pre-historic mystery-centres. Breeding the honeybee from the fig wasp – a sacred deed performed at consecrated sanctuaries – was part of the 'Fig-tree mysteries'. The initiates behind this task developed the ability to commune with the bees' group-soul and to work consciously on the mutual development of the hive and humanity.
This concise but rich work features an illuminating foreword by Heidi Herrmann of the Natural Beekeeping Trust as well as a lucid introduction by translator Paul King that explains the anthroposophical concepts employed by Lorenzen in his text.
>The honey bee has lived in close association with human beings for millennia. Tragically, however, humanity's once intimate connection with this unique creature has been harmed by our increasingly utilitarian and exploitative dealings with the natural world. We are now in urgent need of re-establishing a deeper relationship, not just for the sake of the bees themselves but for the whole of nature – and of course for ourselves.
Lorenzen – a true master beekeeper – provides numerous insights to enable a more fruitful engagement with the living world. Offering an enrichment of the knowledge and practice of beekeeping, he discusses the origins of the honey bee, its relationship to the floral kingdom, the digestion of the bee, the treatment of bee diseases as well as appropriate beekeeping techniques. He also develops subtle spiritual concepts such as the idea of the bee colony as an 'individuality' and 'group-soul', providing new depth and wisdom to our understanding of how bees live and work.

I have a theory to bounce of people here.

Look at all of the sigils for the mystery cults. Bee, wolf, snake, hawk. Suppose then that these cults modeled their behavior and moreover, their plans for society, on the animal that they used to represent them.

What I have here is the idea that the bee cult wanted society to be like a beehive. Wouldn't the snake cult have wanted to be predators on the prey of humans, who were like mice to them? Wouldn't most of the other animals also represent predators?

So, it seems like you can almost divide them up into two categories: those who worship predators and those who worship something else (like a bee).

>>468774460
>For over two thousand years, in the month of Boedromian (September/October), thousands of initiates (_Mystai_) gathered at the Greek town of Eleusis, located around 20k west of Athens, to celebrate the Eleusinian Mysteries.

>It’s vital to remember that most of the sources that give us clues as to what the Eleusinian Mysteries might have been, were written by Christian authors. That’s important for several reasons. These accounts were written centuries after the Mysteries were at the height of their fame, and the fact that they talk about it at all, when the rules explicitly state that initiates should not, suggests they are not eyewitness accounts.

>That said, it’s useful to consider the agenda that some of the sources may have been written in, and these particularly relate to those from the first and second centuries. The objective of these was to do the Church’s bidding, to put an end to polytheism and the worship of these Pagan idols.

>We know that The Eleusinian Mysteries were comprised of two festivals. The Lesser Mysteries, which took place in the spring, and the Greater, which were a far bigger affair, took place, in the autumn, at the time of the harvest. The festivals were to become famous the world over. For the Melissae though, they were just two of the festivals in a larger cycle that celebrated Demeter and her daughter Persephone, The Goddess of Spring. Each festival formed a vital marker that aided the construction of the agricultural Attic calendar.

This is important background. So, there were all of these "mystery rites" in Greece and Rome that the church collectively shutdown while they were spreading Christianity.
>>468776899

>>468774460
>The Passion Play re-enacted Demeter’s refusal to perform her holy duties as Theia, in vengeance for her daughter being stolen from her. The play itself is thought to date back to the Mycenae period (1600 BCE to 1100 BCE) and the cult of Demeter is believed to have been established around 1500 BCE.

>The story honours Demeter, and worships Kore. The initiation promised to help you to develop _kharis_, or grace, with Demeter in this life, with Persephone in death, and then perhaps by extension, some degree of grace with Hades too.

It's probably best to think of a mystery cult as like a symbolic principle that is applicable to other aspects of life. Maybe it's about the beehive which has an analogy to human society. Maybe it's about the stars. Maybe it's an interaction of human-like gods.

What were these rituals? Interestingly, rituals seem very similar to plays. What do plays make you think of? Shakespeare, epic writer of the middle ages. Freemason initiation rituals (you can find the scripts online). "All the world is a stage". The CIA's Mk Ultra research into how memories of media consumption are formed like memories of experiencing the thing. The Radio Project funded by the Rockefellers, also researching how the mind receives messages.

What's really happening here? I think everything you consume (read, watch, hear) becomes part of your psyche, which you can use to reason about the world. There were ancient people who studied many aspects of the natural world, and they preserved this knowledge as mysteries that got passed on as plays and rituals performed for people. Ancient priests were like traveling showmen, maybe.

Among the most important mysteries, which the Eleusians called Greater Mysteries and which the Tarot makers call Greater Arcana, are archetypes of people. The Kabbalistic tree is a tree of archetypes.
>>468774460
https://gynocentrism.com/2021/02/27/the-one-true-masculinity/

>“It should be clear that there is not only one masculine archetype and one feminine archetype. There are dozens, if not hundreds, of feminine and masculine archetypes.

https://gynocentrism.com/2021/05/22/servant-slave-and-scapegoat/

>The classic, historical masculine archetypes of Hero, Villain, Ruler, Warrior, Creator, Sage, Rebel and Explorer, all of which either defined what men chose or what they were driven to be.

>The Manipulator, the Bitch, the Saboteur, the Queen and the Damsel in Distress have usurped the timeless archetypes of mother (Demeter), daughter (Persephone), lover (Aphrodite), civic life and learning (Athena), etc.. 

I believe these are considered the "greater mysteries" because they represent the very core of all arcane knowledge: that which is about ourselves. Gnosis is the greatest mystery of all. This is where people often implicate god.

So what is the effect of shutting down the mysteries?

We literally have less archetypes to work with. Imagine we went from having plays and performances that illustrate how to be all of the things mentioned above, and then we were reduced to just hearing one story over and over and over: about one man, one woman, and one son. This forms sort of a matrix that you can't escape because you can't truly conceive of more ways of being. You must either be a slave or master, and those who are not masters submit as slaves.

Well, slowly over the past 2000 years, we fought back against the church, and with figures like Shakespeare, we reinvigorated the minds of the populace. Today, of course, there are innumerable shows on TV available to watch. Are they teaching you good archetypes though? In many cases, no. Of course not. See, if they couldn't eliminate the archetypes from discussion, they could at least control WHICH alternative archetypes we hear. This is what leads us to the current state of the media.

>So what is the effect of shutting down the mysteries?

makes it so the mind is often untamed and in "fight or flight" due to trauma, think circumcision and church services where "you goto hell unless you do what I say!"
In 1891, Thomas Taylor wrote in his dissertation: _The Eleusinian and Bacchic Mysteries_:

>the Lesser Mysteries signified the miseries of the soul while in subjection to the body. The Greater Mysteries obscurely intimated, by mystic and splendid visions, the felicity of the soul, both here and hereafter, when purified from the defilements of a material nature and constantly elevated to the realities of intellectual [spiritual] vision.

He quotes Plato who does help, a bit, when he says: 

>“The design of the Mysteries was to lead us back to the principles from which we descended, that is to a perfect enjoyment of intellectual [spiritual] good.”

>The Christian Bishop Asterius of Amaseia in Pontus asked of his Pagan readers:
>Are not the mysteries the core of your worship? Are the dark crypt not there and the solemn meeting of the hierophant and the priestess, the two alone together? Are not the torches extinguished while the crowd believes its salvation lies in the things done by the two in the dark?

Curious mention of the hierophant and priestess, two of the early cards of the Tarot.

>>468768186
It's voluntary retard. It doesn't require you to download an app or even use your phone.
It is simply a substitute for other forms of id for when you are compelled to give id online to a private entity. For example when you apply for a rental or when you register a sim card.
Digital ID just means you no longer have to upload an image of your drivers license or passport, and can instead use a more secure form of id that cannot be harvested and used by anyone who gets access to the private entities data.
You're schizing out over literally nothing.

>>468779013

In the midst of our increasingly digitized and mechanized world, it's easy to forget the warnings of a visionary who dared to challenge the status quo. Ted Kaczynski, aka the Unabomber, was more than just a serial bomber; he was a philosopher, a critic, and a prophet who foresaw the dangers of unchecked technological progress.

Kaczynski's manifesto, "Industrial Society and Its Future," is a scathing critique of modern technology and its effects on human autonomy, freedom, and the environment. He argues that technology has become a self-sustaining system that is beyond human control, driving us towards a dystopian future where humans are reduced to mere automatons.

THE ILLUSION OF PROGRESS

Kaczynski's central argument is that technological progress is not synonymous with human progress. In fact, he contends that the relentless pursuit of technological advancement has led to a decline in human autonomy, creativity, and freedom. We have become slaves to our machines, sacrificing our individuality and creativity at the altar of efficiency and convenience.

THE RISE OF THE TECHNOCRACY

The Unabomber's critique of technology is not just a nostalgic longing for a bygone era; it's a warning about the rise of a technocratic elite that seeks to control and manipulate humanity. He argues that the increasing reliance on technology has created a new class of experts who wield immense power over the masses. This technocracy, driven by its own logic and interests, is eroding our democratic institutions and undermining our capacity for self-governance.
THE ENVIRONMENTAL COST

Kaczynski's manifesto also highlights the devastating environmental consequences of unchecked technological progress. The relentless pursuit of growth and efficiency has led to the degradation of our natural world, threatening the very survival of our planet. The Unabomber's warning is clear: if we fail to address the environmental costs of technological progress, we risk destroying the very foundations of human existence.

THE NEED FOR A NEW PATH

So, what's the alternative? Kaczynski advocates for a radical reevaluation of our values and priorities. He proposes a return to a more primitive, decentralized, and autonomous way of life, where humans are not mere cogs in a machine but active participants in shaping their own destiny.

THE UNABOMBER'S LEGACY

Ted Kaczynski's ideas may have been radical, but they were not without merit. His critique of technology and its effects on humanity is a necessary corrective to our blind faith in progress. As we hurtle towards a future of artificial intelligence, biotechnology, and cybernetic enhancements, we would do well to heed the Unabomber's warning: that the price of progress may be too high to pay.

Will we continue down the path of technological tyranny, or will we take a step back and reassess our values? The Unabomber's prophecy is a call to action, a reminder that the future is not set in stone, and that we still have the power to shape our own destiny.

>>468755699
>higher turbulence zones
>altitude
Level 4 turbulence is really the only one that threatens the plane. Flying through level 3 can happen in mountainous areas, coastlines, or any kind of inclement weather. The amount of turbulence needed to break up a plane mid flight or tilt it into a stall would be extraordinary. This person who wrote this might be right about pathways, maybe even reasoning, but his “turbulence zone” thing is total horse shit. Pilots and carriers are constantly being advised on turbulent conditions and how to avoid them. Turbulence videos are 100% bad publicity and there is 0 upside to purposefully flying pilots into turbulence.

>>468778989
wrong thread bot
https://www.palladiummag.com/2024/05/17/my-last-five-years-of-work/
I recently read this article on Palladium Magazine about how the rapid rise of Large Language Models (LLM) risks making humans obsolete in different parts of the economy. When taken to its extreme, the author argues that humans will eventually be completely replaced by artificial general intelligence (AGI), and that we need to prepare for it by being aware of the effects human obsolescence will have on us. I'm not persuaded by the article due to the observations it left unaddressed, so I want an extra set of eyes to see if there is anything I missed. 1/5
>>468773821
The strength of the article rests in it's theorizing about the social and psychological effects of LLM and AGI replacing humans in the workforce. It brings to attention how human's without gainful employment potentially have either negative health effects such as depression and physical health problems (although the author recognizes the causality could be reversed), or positive health effects such as increased reported happiness and free time for other activities such as social rituals, academic study, and artistic expression. The author builds on this by discussing strategies to mentally adapt to our obsolescence, by pursuing activities for the pleasure of it, with the knowledge that something or someone will always surpass your proficiency. Leaning further into it's strength, the article reveals how America's perception of leisure varies based on socioeconomic status, with the poor being condemned as misusing free-time as a resource. The article puts the cultural relationship to the AGI in the workforce on display, and for that it should be celebrated, but it fails to argue that humans will be totally replaced by machines. 2/5
>>468773844
The replacement of humans by LLM or AGI is neither guaranteed, nor universal. The author recognizes that some elements of an economy will be less effected due to the difficulty of LLM and AGI substituting manual dexterous labour and specializations where a human presence has value in itself. This would alter humanity's relation to work, but it would not force humans out of the workforce. Since the wealthiest parts of the world have service sector economies, these societies would be the most effected by LLM and AGI, as it would be easier to replace humans in their more digitally oriented elements. The article acknowledges this by mentioning the job security of the trades. What these machines do not effect are the manual labour jobs that exist in the Global South, which currently cannot be fully automated due to existing hardware restraints. Even if these restrains were to be removed, that does not eliminate human activity from a market economy. An alternative scenario is one in which humans and machines compete for the same jobs, reducing the negotiating position of human workers. AGI still has expenses in the form of energy consumption, maintenance, and operational costs, and if human labour is sufficiently cheap and effective, they could still be selected over software. In order for this to occur, the price of human labour would have to be lowered to be cost competitive, and worker's rights would have to be de-prioritized in order to compete with AGI in economic output. Instead of humans living in a world without work, they might just live in one where our idea of a full-time job only pays ten percent of the monthly costs of food, water, and shelter. 3/5
ok
>>468773881
The opposite of obsolescence is possible as well. AI might create more demand labour though it's maintenance and resource consumption. With its efficiency, not only does its ability to satisfy demand increase, providing the opportunity for new demands, a new suite of tasks to be fulfilled are also created. If the rate of growth of these new tasks exceeds humanity's ability to fulfill them, we can have an increase in the demand for human labour, not a decrease, and if this demand is satiated by more AGI, then the problem is only reproduced, with another set of machines creating more tasks to fulfill. I am still, unconvinced that humans will be obsolete due to the proliferation of AGI, because there is one last refuge of human decision making: normative sense-making. While a machine can determine how to complete a goal in a way that is superior to human judgment and execution, it does not have the capacity to determine the metaphysics, and value judgments that serve as the first premise of any logic chain that leads to the goals, and sub-goals that an AGI would execute, and so the most fundamental of “ought” statements will still be within the exclusive domain of humanity. 4/5
>>468773926
Even though this article starts with the assumption that AGI will replace humans in the workforce and that we need to adapt to it, the premise might not even be realized. We might not be replaced by machines in a market economy, just immiserated by them, or we can end up with more jobs than both humans and AGI can handle. Even if advancements in hardware and software eliminate familiar jobs, we still have control over the subjective, the moral, and the purpose, all generated by a will cannot be challenged so long as humans maintain their hegemony over constructed cognitions. 5/5

>can you out alpha the divorce court?
No. 
Why?
1. It takes forever to get anything done. By the time you're done your kids have aged quite far. 
2. It's stressful. You can't just rely on your lawyer. If you have a GOOD (expensive) one then you might be able to relax a bit, but there is effort necessary on your part, and you should stay on top of things in case your lawyer makes mistakes. 
3. It's costly in terms of money. Doing things twice, bad timing., Example: my divorce cost me dearly, monetarily. She was supposed to get $16k of my retirement fund, since that was half of what accrued while I we were married, but in stead she ended up getting half of ALL my accrual at the time - $30k 
That 30k would be worth at least double that today, sitting in my 401k or my Roth. 
And that that doesn't factor the emotional ride of having to fight her for my kids, and the toll she took my kids trying to brainwash them against me (she didn't). But it still took 4 years and half of my savings at the time. 
And this is playing the game well. I couldn't imagine what it's like for a poor guy.

Yeah weed legalization doesn't really get me going one way or the other. 
I'm pro weed legalization because it would be great to just go to the store and get good quality weed cheaply and easily. 

But I'm anti-weed legalization because you know that they won't legalize it right. 
What I mean by that is that they won't make common strains public domain, while allowing companies to have patented strains. They won't fully make it legal as if it was a tomato plant, it'll come with some gay ass growers permit/license thing. They'll make it so it impacts whether or not you can own a gun. They'll tax the shit out of it so it is still cheaper to get it on the black market rather than just buying it at the store. 

But in terms of availability, Everyone that wants it can get it, honestly. As long as you aren't driving around smoking it in your car for a pig to pull you over and say "I smell weed" and fuck your life up, then you aren't going to be caught with it. As long as you smoke it in a proper place like, at home, and not at a public park or in a movie theater or something stupid. 

So, as a political issue, I really don't care either way. The only thing that gets me is that it is obvious it is going to be legalized (in some form) soon. Why right wingers are hamstringing themselves over it politically is just so retarded. I think the boomers will vote (R) even if you are neutral on weed, and there is no need to turn colleged aged zoomers away by being REEFER MADNESS about weed. When it's going to be legalized anyway. Why give your opponent ammunition? It just doesn't make any sense.

Fire weather and fire behaviour expert here. What do you want to know? 

Firstly, one of the main problems we have is that for the last century of so, we’ve had a zero tolerance policy when it comes to forest fires. As a result, the duff layer in the forests has continued to build year over year, and as the weather warms due to climate change (which is happening, but not that alarming), we are seeing larger more impactful wildfires. This is particularly true in the boreal. 

What you are seeing in the gif is a heli torch helicopter likely from BC.

>Backfiring is a firefighting technique that involves intentionally starting a fire in front of an active wildfire to consume fuel, block the wildfire's path, or change its direction. Backfiring is a variation of the controlled burn technique, where firefighters burn fuel in the path of the wildfire to stop it from advancing or redirect it.

>>468773315
Well, sort of. If you have a full crown fire (combustion reaches the tree canopy), you can have “spotting,” where ignited firebrands (ember) are carried high into the air by convection forces and can travel more than a km ahead of the fire front.

>>468773692
We use forecasted weather and topography to our advantage and predict the spread as best we can using deterministic wildland fire growth simulation software, such as Prometheus, FireCast, etc. 

The intention is to burn available fuels ahead of the fire front to, as best we can, influence the direction of spread. For the big Rank 5 and Rank 6 fires, you cannot extinguish them, only influence the direction of spread away from values at risk.

>>468775201
It's nothing to do with the world, it was always like that, it's your awareness that's different. Your perception of the state of politics has a lot to do with the medium you perceive it through. The paradigm before the modern day was television, that persisted basically through the 2010s. Television is very centralized as only a few companies had the capacity to broadcast news channels. This meant that a few centralized companies decided what constituted "the news" or "the issues," so they could focus you onto a few at a time (of their choosing) and you felt like things were more controlled.

Now of course you live in the age of social media and free internet. Even with the centralization of the internet, it's centralized around user-operated websites that corporations desperately censor rather than deciding what the narrative is before even word one is said. That means that now you have literally billions of people trying to grab the mic and get you to care about their specific issue, which leads to chaos and the perception of chaos.

Life isn't different, you're just more aware of the chaos than you would've been 50 years ago; and especially, you're far more aware of counter-narratives to your own state's narrative than you ever could've been with television. 

If you'd been born in 1650, you'd hear about the news from Florence or wherever a few weeks after it happened. You'd tend your animals and not give a shit.

That looks like it fast disappearing.

>Steven Paul Jobs was born in San Francisco, California, on February 24, 1955, to Joanne Carole Schieble and Abdulfattah "John" Jandali (Arabic: عبد الفتاح الجندلي). Abdulfattah Jandali was born in a Muslim household to wealthy Syrian parents, the youngest of nine siblings. After obtaining his undergraduate degree at the American University of Beirut, Jandali pursued a PhD in political science at the University of Wisconsin. 

>There, he met Joanne Schieble, an American Catholic of Swiss-German descent whose parents owned a mink farm and real estate in Green Bay. The two fell in love but faced opposition from Schieble's father due to Jandali's Muslim faith. When Schieble became pregnant, she arranged for a closed adoption, and travelled to San Francisco to give birth.[3]

>>468768933
>But isn't the point of this entirely to re-sell at an higher value than you bought?
If you were to create a brand new currency tomorrow, and it was done in a completely free and open way (it wasn't just the government saying you have to use it to pay your taxes or you have to accept it as wages or at your business). Such a currency, would have to prove itself. You would get people trying it just as a novelty, like to test it out. Others just give it away for another currency because they assume it's a fad and won't last. Regardless of the reasons, the more it's used, and the more people don't want get rid of it (let's say you'd rather use your Euros to pay for something than send it). Then you actually start to see it form a store of value. But it has to earn that. Such a process would certainly take years. When you understand Bitcoin properly, you won't want to just use your Euro to buy it to get more Euro. Especially that is depreciating due to inflation. Speculation and price swings are expected since it's still a small market, think of the market size like water, the smaller it is, the easier it is to make big waves. As it gets bigger it gets, they harder it is to do that.

>>468758031
According to The Episcopal Church website, like the grim reaper, the role of a verger — sometimes called the "protectors of the procession" — date back to the Middle Ages. But unlike a death ripper, they're nothing to be afraid of. They're typically full or part-time lay ministers or community volunteers. Traditionally, vergers dress in black robes, just like the figure briefly seen at King Charles III's coronation, and they hold a mace — the object that appeared to some like a scythe in the coronation footage.

the "alchemical wedding", the marriage (chemical reaction) of the opposites (different substances) makes something else, different from both source elements
it's an allegory about the basics of medieval research in chemistry, from before any fundamental understanding of atoms, molecules, elements or chemical reactions
so the alchemists interpreted that as opposite principles of a man/sun getting frisky with the woman/moon and giving birth to a bird/soul that was one more step on the quest for the philosophical stone, which was either a complete comprehension of the laws of nature or a recipe for immortality and transmuting lead into gold
the idea was funny enough that lots of secret societies included it in the random shit their members were lucky enough to exchange with each other, plus there was a naked chick

HEB prices right now:
$2.00 pre-made 1/4lb burger patty
$0.30 for a hamburger bun (8 pack 2.40)
$0.30 for a slice of cheese
$0.50 for a slice of onion, a slice of tomato, a squirt of mayo, couple of lettuce leaves

That's $3.10 in ingredients. Takes less time to make it than to drive to McD, and will taste better too. You do have to buy some stuff, but you get to re-use them across several burgers.

If you buy your own ground chuck beef and make it into a patty, it's $3.50 for a pound, or about 85c per patty.

>>468745733

I have slowly been thinking about how to reduce my tech use. At first I thought using less powerful retro tech would do it but I have come to realize that the simplest tech is not even electric at all. 

Notebooks and pens for drawing and writing, actual physical books including language methods instead of learning online or using an e-reader, acoustic guitar instead of electric or even instead of listening to recorded music. Wood carving/whittling is a fun hobby that is as low tech as possible. Sport does not require any tech as well. Gardening too. Boardgames instead of video games.

I can go to the cinema to see movies, venues to see live show but keep my home tech as low as possible.

We cultivated food and generated heat for eons before electricity. Growing up in the 70s electricity was used for lighting and heat, and some infrastructure technology obviously, but also later Jewish shit like TV and especially the internet. When I was a kid I had a crystal radio I built that did not need batteries. Computers can go back to operating on punch cards and mechanical clockwork devices. 
I could go without cell phones the internet and computers, I spent the first decade of my life without it. ICE vehicles would have to be hand cranked to start for example. Big deal. Hydro power for electricity or even coal is old tech. We made do with horses for thousands of years. 
I see it as a net gain after a few years of adjustment. I don't think anyone will really miss the internet over time, in 2024 it's basically dead and overrun by bots and porn anyway. It can go on the trash heap too.

>>468764662
https://streamable.com/mjmtzb
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1107.5728.pdf
The network of global corporate control
Stefania Vitali, James B. Glattfelder and Stefano Battiston
>The structure of the control network of transnational corporations affects global market competition and financial stability. So far, only small national samples were studied and there wasno appropriate methodology to assess control globally. We present the first investigation of the architecture of the international ownership network, along with the computation of the control held by each global player. We find that transnational corporations form a giant bow-tie structure and that a large portion of control flows to a small tightly-knit core of financial institutions.This core can be seen as an economic “super-entity” that raises new important issues both for researchers and policy makers.

> a large portion of control flows to a small tightly-knit core of financial institutions.This core can be seen as an economic “super-entity”
> a large portion of control flows to a small tightly-knit core of financial institutions.This core can be seen as an economic “super-entity”

>>468766251
https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2205.14135
This problem has been solved by flash attention and chain of thought prompts. It's not processing the full movie in real time, it's taking clips of a second or two, processing them then adding information to it's RAG database. You can interrupt that process at any time to then prompt it to ask questions about what it's already seen and because it's searching through a vectorized database where every entry has multiple keywords attached to it, it can find information on things like what a character has been doing. This is *possible* right now, the question is how much of the $20/month subscription is subsidised by government agencies who want to FILL those vector databases with realtime LLM generated insights about their citizens.

Garamendi Announces Winners of Congressional High School Art Competition

The grand prize winner was Micaela Huang of Berkeley High School with her piece, "Me: A Gen-Z Girl." Micaela’s work will be displayed at the U.S. Capitol for a year in a gallery featuring winners from Congressional Districts throughout the country.

Raven Guilas of Jesse Bethel High School, with her piece "Internet History," was the runner-up. Chelsey Greene of Buckingham Collegiate Charter Academy was the Solano County winner, and Iris Yu of Albany High School was the Contra Costa County winner.

The People’s Choice Award, which goes to the most liked photo of submissions on Facebook, was awarded to Natalia Perez of Early College High School for her piece, “Expectations Over Exhaustion.”


"Congratulations to Micaela Huang for winning this year's competition. She has a rare gift, and I hope she continues to follow her dreams. The competition was stiff, and there were many impressive pieces. I also want to congratulate the other artists we highlighted this year with special merit, including our runner-up, Raven Guilas of Jesse Bethel High School," Garamendi said.

https://garamendi.house.gov/media/press-releases/garamendi-announces-winners-congressional-high-school-art-competition-3

>The Eridani Edict, or Epsilon Eridani Edict, was a unilateral prohibition passed by the Solarian League, aimed at preventing widespread slaughter of civilians. The edict laid out the exact conditions under which an attack could be made against an inhabited planet's surface, and gave the Solarian League Navy the authority to destroy "any government or star nation or rogue mercenary outfit" responsible for a violationary attack.

>The Edict didn’t offer a blanket protection for noncombatants. For example, if a belligerent struck a planetary defense center located in the middle of a metropolitan area, killing many civilians, this probably would not violate the Edict “if the attacker does everything possible to restrain the effect of the attack on the population as a whole.”
